physDesc.p: This letter consists of four typed pages on carbon paper. The upper left corner of the first page contains an address line. The upper right of each page contains a dateline. The third page is damaged along the right side of the paper as it seems to have been crumbling. The fourth page has some of the same damage alongside the right edge. Each page after the first has a heading above the dateline (Mr. Aldington - [Page #]).

div.p: You must think me very strange never to have written to you after getting the letter telling me of your father's sudden death; but, as Mrs. Russell has written you, I had to have another operation, which makes three in fifteen months. It was impossible for me to write anything - even dictate anything. I have thought of you so often, and only wish that I had been nearer and could do anything for you in person. The breaking up of old ties, even if one has not lived with one's parents for years, is a dreadful thing.

I sent you a copy of my new volume, “Legends,” which I was unable to write in, as I only received it about two days after my operation. I wonder if you ever got it. My secretaries think that it was sent to Malthouse Cottage, Padworth, Reading, Berks, but they may have sent it to your old address, The Author's Club. If you never received the book, I will send you another. I cannot think that you will like it particularly. It is perhaps too much in my own particular idiom to give you much pleasure; by which I mean that I think your taste runs toward a more peaceful type of verse.

Harriet Monroe tells me that you have resigned as her foreign correspondent, telling her that you found yourself getting more conservative as you grew older; if so, it is interesting. I do not find any such thing in myself. I dislike freaks as much as I ever did, but I dearly love evolutionary experiments.

I have a volume of Chinese translations - which I am doing with my friend Mrs. Francis Ayscough of Shanghai, China - coming out this Autumn. Of course these innumerable operations have taken a great deal of my strength,
and I have not been able to do as much work as I should like, in consequence, but I am getting round again, and it looks as if this one might be successful, but then, it has looked that way before, one really cannot tell, and nothing but time can give us any idea as to whether it has been successful or not. The Summer has been spent mostly in an arm-chair trying to get up strength. I crawl round the garden a little; and, by the way, that description of yours of the hill opposite your house is too lovely, with all its beautiful flowers. I wish you could see my garden. It is not wild, merely a garden, but I am devotedly fond of it and manage to keep it in bloom from April to November.

My present plans are to finish my “Life of Keats” this Winter, put it through the press before I leave, and sail for England sometime next Spring or early Summer; that is, supposing this operation is successful. There is so much suppose about this that I have not engaged my passages yet, but if all goes well by January I think I shall. You say that you think I should keep criticism and biography apart in my “Life of Keats,” but that is not exactly my idea, although perhaps we may mean nearer the same thing than it sounds as if we did. I want to give a more comprehending and psychological biography than has ever yet been done of him. I agree with you entirely that a great deal of his work is very, very poor. The rest of it is pure genius. That I hope to point out. Of course I shall pick out the things that I think are genius, and not the things that the world does necessarily. For instance, I have no use for the “Hyperion” in either form, and many people consider it his best work. Again I think “The Eve of St. Mark” a marvellous (sic) thing, and only a very few critics have given it any consideration whatever. But there will be a great deal of biography. I am having an awful time with
some curmudgeons over here who have original documents that they will not allow me to use. I speak as if there were millions of these men; on the contrary, there are only two. Most of the people who have manuscripts are only too glad to put them at my disposal. Since writing my centenary address at Yale last Winter, I have done nothing but collect material for my biography. I do not intend to do anything about getting the thing together or starting writing until I get this Chinese book off my hands. Then, in November, my lectures begin again, and it is no little problem to fit them in in nice tidy packages and have plenty of time in between the layers of lectures to do the Keats book, so you see I am busy.

And you, I imagine, are extremely busy too, judging from Harriet Monroe's account of your letter to her. What has happened to Flint? I never received a word from him, after I wrote him as you asked me to do after his wife's death. I have never even received any acknowledgement from him of having received the money that I sent through you. I am sending you two drafts for the half-year anthology royalties, one for him again. I wish those little books would go out of print. I think the time for them is past, and they will be of more interest collected with great labour at second hand by enthusiasts; but they seem to have a great many sheets on hand, and they keep selling, as you see. Of course they will have to be sold while the printers have them to sell. I have ordered them not to reprint, as you know.

I see many pleasant things in the papers about your “Medallions in Clay,” but I am puzzled to know why you cribbed your title from Henri de Régnier. Our Chinese book is called “Fir-Flower Tablets,” “fir-flower” being the name of the paper on which poetry was frequently written. It is an
attractive name, I think. I do not know whether you ever see “The Dial.” There are two poems of mine in the August number that I rather like.

Do write when you get this and tell me all your news, and let me know if you got “Legends,” because, above all things, don't let us get out of touch just because the ocean separates us and we have not met for seven years.
